Just Cause 2 is a legendary over the shoulder sandbox shooter along the lines of Grand Theft Auto without the charm. The game focuses on destruction, deep controls and doing whatever craziness you'd like to do. You play as Rico Rodriguez and you've been sent in by the government to mess things up like a kitten in tissue paper on an island nation that seems giant by gaming standards. You have the option work for different factions / gangs that have their own agendas. The gangs are a nice touch and you'll see them battle each other on the island while civilians run and hide. Its a nice AI dichotomy.  Since the game is set on a bunch of giant islands, the terrain is gorgeous and diverse. You'll see lush green jungles beneath icy mountains, then go into those icy mountains and down into sandy deserts. After that, you can take a boat for a ride across beautiful blue waters, then hijack a jet and surf on top of it into a golden sunset while dodging missiles. Everywhere in this game is a gorgeous place and there are tons of places to visit and blow up. There doesn't seem to be any interiors, but that is fitting for a game so beautiful with good traversal diversity.  The controls are deep, but they allow you to do a lot more than your average over the shoulder sandbox shooter. You have your standard, run, jump, gunfire, reload, grenade, toggle guns, toggle grenades buttons, but you also have the infamous grapple hook. This hook is what the Bionic Commando reboot was missing. Double pressing it will send you instantly zipping to wherever it latched onto. Traversal is made super easy, climbing up buildings with the hook, but not just that, but you have a parachute that is used to glide around. Simply hit the jump button while in the air to deploy the chute. Pressing and holding the grappling hook will grapple something, but then when you hold it, aim at something else and release the button, you've now tethered two things together, which results in hilarity. Tether a moving car to the ground, to watch the car flip over. Tether a NPC to a rocketing propane tank and watch them blast off. Not just that, but there is plenty of car combat. Normal games would have you just get in a car, not this game, you can get on top of the car to shoot things, or you can slip down in front or behind the car to shoot things using the car for cover as its moving. You can take over moving vehicles, with easy quick time events that show a struggle instead of just kicking a person out from behind the wheel.  Combat is pretty easy, you just aim the cursor and fire. There is no aim button, if your cursor is remotely near anyone or anything, you will see a red highlight around the logical target. So if you the player have terrible aim, Rico Rodriguez will still shoot the target. In terms of holding guns, you can hold one two handed gun and two one handed guns. There are throwable explosives and you can toggle between two types. You can also melee enemies with the grappling hook.  With so much control freedom, you can tackle missions any way that you want. Such as a car chase mission where you need to escort the driver, do you grappling hook vehicle to vehicle, taking out enemies and struggling to knock out the driver? Do you tether the other vehicles to the ground and watch them crash, or do you use your parachute to hover over the action and blow up the other vehicles? The choice is yours. It is an excellent game to do what you want.  Missions themselves give you easy to follow objectives as if they were steps to follow. Open the gate, take out that rocket launcher, take out those snipers, pick up that item, grapple onto that helicopter, and so on. The objectives are marked with red and easily found with how far away they are. If you try to deviate too far from a mission location, the game will warn you and start a 10 second counter. This keeps the intensity on and prevents people like me from exploiting things.  Outside of missions, there are plenty of things to do and they're all marked on your map. Well you need to visit the location marked on your map before you find what it is there to do. Things such as races, time trials, destroy bases and loot villages. Destroying locations and looting villages each has a percentage attached to it. To loot a village, you need to find 100% of things hidden there. Things like vehicle parts, weapon parts, cash boxes and even liberate the village from propaganda buses. Thankfully when you get near something findable, it will show up pointing out where you are, but you need to be very near it. This saves you from detailed searching. It is the same for ammo boxes and health cabinets.  As for the bases, you need to find things and blow up things such as towers, generators, gas tanks, communication towers and surface-to-air missile launchers, each will make up 100%. It is fun for explorers to seek out every nook and cranny, but I can understand if getting 100% would feel like a chore.  When you create chaos or break any sort of law, the local military will be sent after you. At first it'll be simple things hunting you down, but if you keep creating chaos, your 'heat' level will go up and more soldiers will come after you. How do you reduce your heat level? Hide. Yep hide in the jungle and after time your red heat will go to orange heat and start dropping down. This is good for keeping the focus on what you were doing before you created heat. With plenty of jungle in the game, it is pretty easy to ditch any heat you might have.  Sadly the enemies feel pretty dumb. No one takes cover when you're putting bullets into them, even if enemies are next to cover, but I guess people play for the fun of doing what they want, not the challenge. In car chases enemy vehicles will just ram other objects. It leads to some laughable moment. They'll just drive off cliffs when you hit the brakes. I can understand scripted events like running into a gas station, but otherwise it is hilariously bad.  The game is pretty easy even on normal with regenerating health. Not just that, but health pickups from cabinets seem well placed. If you die, you go to the last checkpoint. Sometimes the checkpoints are further back than you think, but that's the only thing that really presents a punishment in the game.  The real downside to the game is that it seems to crash once every few hours back to the desktop. Luckily the game has an autosave feature.  To top all of that off, there is a free Multiplayer MOD that allows every player into one world together for chaos to ensue. Is it worth $15? Sure.... but it has been on sale before at $2.50. Keep that in mind.

I never got around to play the original Just Cause. Mainly because my computer has always had issues with it, and Just Cause 2 pretty much improves the first game in all levels. Just Cause 2 is a third-person action game, and when I say action game I mean crazy jumping-from-airplanes-and-blowing-up-cities - sort of an action game. Rico, the protagonist, is like James Bond on steroids. You can pretty much do whatever you want, in a world at least twenty times (!) bigger than San Andreas, and five times bigger than World of Warcraft.   Pick your vehicle; helicopter, airplane, sports car, moped, tuk tuk etc. and pick a random location; beach, jungle, city, highway, mountain etc. to ram, stunt, blow up, crash, projectile etc. with it. Or just hook yourself to someones boat and enjoy the eyecandies of this tropical paradise. Or hook the same guy's boat into an airplane, and see him take off. Or hook the airplane to a skyscraper and see it torpedo into a ball of flames. Your choice.  The grappling hook, amongst other things, is what lift this game up from the pleasant, boring and realistic open-world games. You can use this Godly thing to pretty much survive any situation. Are you falling from insane height? No problem, just hook towards the ground and survive - Or just precipitate your parachute, that works too. It lacks actually physics though, you can't use your hook to decapitate moped drivers for example, a feature that I would want for Just Cause 3!  Sure the game is far from being realistic and serious, but with great looks, insanely huge map and more vehicles and weapons than you can count - who cares if it's unrealistic? You can stand on a plane while towing another one mid-air, for God's sake! I completely recommend this title if you are even remotely intersted in action, open-world and/or just plain time-consuming roaming and freedom. There is currently a third-party mod in the works, adding Multiplayer. It adds a whole new meaning to the already balls-chaotic world, and makes it go beyond the edge.   Pick this game up, if you have not already! It's been on a billion sales.

Just Cause 2 brings much needed improvement upon the first game's format. Improving in almost every conceivable way, it turned a game which was riddled with problems and a repetitive nature into an enjoyable experience. It's far from perfect, story falling into the stupid and cliche once more, but at least somewhat satirical this time, if it was meant to be taken seriously then the voice acting certainly didn't help. Just Cause 2 can also crash on systems well above recommended requirements albeit rare.   Besides those points, there's a lot to like. The soundtrack is better than ever and perfect for the game. Graphics are great and polished, assuming you can overlook the forced depth of field (developers please stop this.) The world is expansive yet detailed with various areas like mountain regions, cities and deserts to explore and complete. Quality of gameplay as a whole has improved drastically with better controls, intuitive combat including use of grapple, better side activates, missions and creative bosses.   Avalanche studios put real effort in between JC1 and 2 and it shows. It's a much more enjoyable game, sure it can be repetitive going for 100%, but I still got a solid 18 hours out of the game without completing it fully. So I recommend picking it up for anyone interested in an open world sandbox all about causing chaos then go for it.

This should have been the gamers' game of the year.   will start off from the very thing that got me hooked to this game. It's the map. This game has the second biggest game map ever created to date (I was told that FUEL has the biggest map which is 5,560 square miles)  Just cause 2 map is 37 by 37 kilometers. A couple of kilometers on each side of the square map is water, so let's go by 35 by 35 kilometers. Multiply 35 by 35 and there you go - you have 1,225 square kilometers of map to explore, give or take 100 square kilometers.  For the comparison, let's take the Fallout 3 map. That map is about 35 square kilometers. The Oblivion 4 map is roughly the same size. GTA 3 is 35-36 square kilometers GTA 4 is 15 square kilometers And I thought the Far Cry 2 map was huge. It's 50 square kilometers. The ARMA 2 map was definitely the biggest one before Just Cause 2 stepped in. The most important reason why i bought the disappointingly unoptimized ARMA 2 is to simply explore the roughly 400 square kilometers map.  I remember wondering when I was younger if they would ever make a big enough map for a game which I could explore for days and days and days. I thought they finally did that with Arma 2, and despite the fact that I still could not play the game on maximum settings even when my rig should have easily taken on almost 2 ARMA 2's (According to the 'recommended settings'), I still loved the fact that I could enjoy the country-side that I haven't been to in years.  The second thing is that we ACTUALLY have directx 10 in this game. FINALLY, how many more directx 9 games are we going to have? We have directx 11 already, so what's the deal? The directx 10 pretty much seals the deal and completes the game map that I still cannot believe they made. I also cannot believe that the entire game fits on a DVD, how the HELL do they pull that off? shouldn't the map this size be at least 30 GB? I mean Age of Conan: Hyborian Adventure is like a 30-35 GB game.  Well, the third thing is... Ah what the hell, you know the rest. Complete freedom of action, unrealistic stunts, the temporary to permanent abandonment of the laws of physics, infinite parachute, a hundred of drivable vehicles, a cute Easter egg, the Hatch from the first and second seasons of LOST, the pleasure of having to spend 20 minutes just to fly from one end of the map to another on a stolen government jet, the joy of swimming in the sea (wish they had sharks though), the eye candy explosions that you never get tired off, the realistic driving of the vehicles (aside from the way they rotate in mid air sometimes), the realistic damage to the PARTS OF THE VEHICLES THAT WERE ACTUALLY DAMAGED IN THE IMPACT, I could go on and on about this game  Im also playing this game on IMPOSSIBLE and find it quite easy to beat. You just move constantly, shoot (There is sadly a default auto-aim option enabled that you cannot disable) and press 'tab' or whatever you have to evade bullets. HOWEVER, a nearby grenade explosion is almost guaranteed to kill you, so for MAXIMUM realism, I recommend playing this game on IMPOSSIBLE  Im not gonna complain about the check point system, I love the checkpoint system. it makes games more challenging. Plus there still is a SAVE option, although it doesnt work in its original meaning  The story is blah. Who cares? Some of the missions that they give you though are somewhat original and a breath of fresh air from some of the repetitive GTA missions. However, most of those missions are, attack, kill, destroy, blow up, move on. It would have been nice if they added an element of stealth to the game though. It would feel great if could actually play as a somewhat silent or stealthy lethal saboteur. I would also like it if they imposed a penalty for killing civilians both on purpose and incidentally.  I know this game won't win the game of the year award since there is no real substance I guess, but unofficially, this will probably be the gamer's choice No 1 game of 2010. (I hope Metro 2033 wins the game of the year though, which I rationally know it won't)  This game is a pinnacle of guilty pleasure if I can say that. It absorbs so much of my time that I barely have enough time for myself, and its only my second-third day of playing the game. For the third day in the row I come to work late with blood-shot eyes. I actually prefer to staying home and playing this game all weekend and after that, instead of going out with my gf. That's how much impact this game had on me.  If you are an extremely busy person with a busy schedule, i do not recommend playing this game until you find some time to kill, otherwise you'd get the plants vs zombies syndrome, where you cannot stop playing the game and start missing out on life. But I guess, now it's gonna be the Just cause 2 syndrome  I don't want to get emo about this but I'll say honestly that it's actually games like these that make me sorta happy that I was born with enough luck and resources to actually play them, but I'm only speaking for myself here.  Until then, the most rational case for you is to buy this game, support the developers and enjoy it fully until your eyes bleed and your brain melts, since forgetting about reality as much as possible should be the just cause of all gamers.

TLDR? Just buy it and see for yourself. 10/10  It is truly sinful that I waited until now to play this game. While the story is laughable, it really sets the stage for what this game is all about: grappling hooks and parachutes. I've been an advocate for strong storylines and atmosphere in games for years now, but this game alone has really reminded me of what it feels like to play a game purely for fun. To further sweeten the pot, this game has aged really well.  Pros: -MASSIVE open world that lets you do everything from deepsea dive to skydive. No place is off limits right from the start. -A wealth of vehicles, allowing you numerous options for transportation. -Diverse environments including deserts, jungles, cities, oceans, and snowy mountain ranges. -Various weapons, including miniguns with infinite ammo for over-the-top rambo vs. helicopter scenes. -The best grappling hook I've ever used in a game.  -Playable on lower-end machines. I am experiencing zero lag on my Asus with GeForce GTX 560M with 8gb ram.   Cons: -Poor optimization. Expect bugs and the possibility of a little extra work to get this game running smoothly.  (This was especially true with my Nvidia graphics card) -Forgettable story. While some of the characters are interesting, there wont be much to hold your attention here.  -Initially confusing mechanics. It may take a little while to get acclimated to moving around with the hook and chute.  Overall, this is a suprisingly fun experience that will easily consume countless hours of your time if you let it. For me, it's a wonderful way to decompress after a full day of work.   10 grappling hooks out of 10

Just Cause 2 is honestly a fantastic game. You are put in the shoes of agent Rico Rodriguez as he is sent to the South East Asian archipelago of Panau to hunt down his old mentor and do whatever it takes to remove dictator Pandak Panay. A Just Cause indeed. If the other reviews on this page are any indication then it is obvious this game is good enough to define its genre. In fact, if you still haven't got it there is literally no better time than now. Since Just Cause 3 has come out recently, you may question why get this game instead? Although Just Cause 3 is a natural progression from Just Cause 2 and has better visuals and gameplay, this game is still brilliant in it's own right.  Gameplay: This game's gameplay is innovative, exciting and somehow doesn't get old. It can only really be described as a mashup of Michael Bay, James Bond and a monster truck rally. The goal of the game is to destroy chaos objects and cause chaos in Panau, and the game gives you the tools to do this. The game's patented grapple hook is Rico's signature weapon and can be used to 'creatively' kill the countless grunts of the Panauan military as well as tearing down various governmental assets. Rico also has access to a variety of weapons which can all be acquired via the Black Market and can be upgraded to cause even more mayhem. There are well over 300 settlements in Panau to 'liberate' of Panay's military assets and each is filled to the brim with weapon parts and vehicle parts to upgrade your black market items. Despite there being so much to do, the tools given to Rico, including over 100 seperate vehicles, don't make this momentous task boring. And even after all that, there are still races which can be completed in various vehicles and skydives which can be of varying difficulty. Despite this gameplay can eventually get repetitive (you find that after 150 hours and getting 99.4% completion) because the things you blow up don't come back, unlike petrol stations in Just Cause 3. Speaking of which there is a glitch in the game which prevents you from getting 100%, so don't waste your time trying to get that without a relevant mod. The AI in this game can be variable, sometimes being very good and sometimes involving an enemy pilot flying into the side of the Berawan Besar mountains. Overall the gameplay in this game is 9 out of 10  Open World The world of Panau is vast, with 400 square kilometers to explore, Panau is vibrant. The world is varied as well with mountains, jungles, deserts and the sweeping metropolis of Panau City. Honestly the open world in itself is enough to sell this game providing Rico plenty of room to cause mayhem. The world also features many distinct landmarks such as Panau Falls Casino, Three Kings Hotel, Panau International Airport and the infamous Mile High Club. This ultimately creates the best open world in the Just Cause series and possibly one of the best in gaming ever. The game even provides fast travel to make travelling around the vast world that bit more convenient. The destructiblity of this world is pretty astounding when you consider the amount of possible versions of Panau there could be. The only cons are that some civilian settlements and military bases can seem a bit copy-pasteish at times and large amounts of Panau actually is covered in jungle which you can't really do much in, these things I've found aren't actually an issue in Just Cause 3. Overall another 9 out of 10  Performance Just Cause 2 should have no issue running on any modern gaming computer, or even just a normal computer. It is well optimised with few frame drops (on a worthy computer) and the graphics are highly customisable to allow performance tweaks. Yes, lag is possible, particularly on more casual computers but load times are normally quick, unlike its successor. Overall an 8 out of 10  Graphics While not meeting the standard of Just Cause 3, the graphics in this game are superb, with vast draw distances and pretty graphics. Generally blurred textures aren't super common (mostly found on rockfaces) and the water looks fantastic. This game lends itself to fantastic views across Panau and I don't have much to criticise about the game's graphics. The only con I can think of is that the trees in Panau can look a bit papery, perhaps because the tree leaves are actually 2D sprites that change direction to face you (Just Cause 3 has this same issue) Overall a 7.5 out of 10  OST and sounds While the OST in this game is nothing special, as there is actually a distinct lack of music in Just Cause 2, the sounds are actually pretty solid. Explosions are satisfying and gun shots echo through the jungles with reverberation. Music is mostly heard during races and when Rico has heat, but although fits the mood very well, isn't anything memorable Overall a 3 out of 10 for music, but that increases to 6 when sounds are considered  Story Your typical Just Cause story. Dictator rules island nation with iron fist and has plans of world domination. 'Department of Infrastructure Improvement' Rico Rodriguez comes along, causes chaos, dictator shoots nuke but plan backfires. The story isn't bad, but it isn't good either. Just Cause 3 does have a better story, but again if you're looking for story, avoid this genre altogether. Characters are mostly forgettable with only Tom Sheldon really being super memorable, but the story and faction missions are good. This game knows how to not take itself seriously, so in reality the story doesn't really matter, just don't be disappointed. Cutscenes do have action, but they sometimes have a habit (particularly on slower computers) of having the sound and video go out of sync, leading to painful cutscenes that just don't work. Overall story gets a 5 out of 10.  Multiplayer This game itself has no multiplayer aspects, but there is an offical multiplayer mod which is free after buying the game, which is honestly fantastic, and I wish they'd make a multiplayer mod for JC3. Personally I recommend the NerdCubed Fan Server as it is the most popular server found on JC2MM. Speaking of other mods, this game has a great modding community which leads to an even more chaotic game.  Overall this game is fantastic, and I consider it a must buy for anyone who enjoys a bit of chaos, particularly as it is only £10. Yo uwon't be disappointed. Overall this game is 8.5 out of 10.

Just Cause 2 is an impressive sandbox game with a gigantic map. It's pretty cool! I'll give it a review.  GAMEPLAY: Just Cause 2's gameplay like a stereotypical action movie - turned up to eleven. It's got an open-world GTA-like format with cars, planes, guns, and boats. The map is HUGE. It makes Grand Theft Auto's playing field look tiny. If traversing a map this big sounds difficult, dno't worry - you play as a dude called Rico, who is basically the latino spiderman. As Rico, you can use your grappling hook as much as you like to grab onto anything and launch yourself in that direction. A really cool feature is that you can latch your grappling hook onto a car to hijack it extremely quickly. You can also do crazy stunts and deploy parachutes whenever you like. That's right - Rico basically farts parachutes. There's lots of guns, explosions, and all kinds of crazy things. You can do missions, but to unlock missions you must cause lots of chaos first - which is good because blowing up things while in police pursuit is EXTREMELY fun.  PRESENTATION: The game is absolutely gorgeous. The island of Panau looks amazing and relaxing. The explosions are huge and dramatic. The gunplay looks cool and cinematic. There's not much I can really say about the graphics except that they look great in all aspects. Perhaps not the most realistic, but the game is a few years old, so it's to be expected. Music is nice but there's not much variety so it may get a bit repetetive.  STORY: Not the game's strongest suit. The story is rather lacking compared to something like Fallout or Half-Life. Sure, it's there, but it's not pulitzer-prize caliber stuff. The story never gets in the way of the gameplay because it's really not that important.  I'd have to say that Just Cause 2 is definitely worth buying. It's fun and allows for hours of non-stop gameplay. If you like Grand Theft auto or similar open-world games, you should definitely try this one. Just cause 2 isn't perfect, but it is one big fun, explosion-packed adventure with tons of things to destroy and bad guys to defeat. Can't wait until Just Cause 3 comes out!

GTA on steroids, I got this on sale for $3 and is probably the best $3 I have spent, however, the normal price of $15 is still worth it if you don't want to wait for a sale. Best of all there's no waiting to get your hands on awesome hardware like helicopters or rocket launchers (plenty of enemies and places with them). Probably the most overpowered weapon/ability is your grappling hook, which you start with and always have. Enemy on a mounted turret? Just grapple him and pull him off. Attack helicopter on your butt? Grapple it and punch the pilot out and take it over. No vehicle to get around? Just grapple onto a tree, mountain side, tall building, etc. and from there grapple onto another tree/cliff side/building/etc. If you get high enough (via grappling) you can jump and open a parachute (which is always available) while falling and grapple the ground (or other object) to move yourself in that direction. Then there's attaching two objects (including enemies) together, such as attaching a soldier to a passing car, or a helicopter to a military truck/tank... physics will do the rest for you. Its main limitation is its range, but its not painfully short.   Also there's a Multiplayer Mod that as of this writing is in early but playable stages and I believe is free. Ex: you can attach a tank to a helicopter and have a friend fly while you're in the tank shooting the cannon. It is also loads of fun and should only continue to get better with updates.

In that small, tiny, free slice of the game I got at least 15 hours of gameplay. The actual full game has dozens of times more content than the demo, and all of it is just as fun, if not more fun, than the demo.  At first look, it just looks like any other action shooter, but this is so much more. The brilliant idea of including a grappling hook that can pull you to any location was pure gold. Whoever thought of that should get a very large cut of the profit. Combining the grappling hook, parachute, vehicles, combat, explosives and tons of other things is simply said, some of the most fun I've ever had playing video games.  Vehicles and driving are fairly solid, but I would prefer better controller support on the pc since there are sensitivity issues while driving cars, but everything else is fine. Especially helicopters. There are few things as fun as flying around high above danger, shooting miniguns and rockets at enemies below while simultaneously hijacking chopper after chopper as enemy pilots attempt to take you down.  Not only is the gameplay solid, but the graphics look amazing (on pc at least). Panau island is a beautiful place, and I sometimes just decide to jump into a jet and fly across the massive, beautifully detailed island. And that's another thing, did I mention the size of the game? Panau Island has over 400 square miles of glorious sandboxy goodness for you to do whatever the heck you want. Whether that be taking over enemy bases and strongholds, blowing up everthing in sight, finding creative ways to kill enemies, just admiring the scenery, playing evil knievel in all the possible vehicles, or all of the above, Just Cause 2 is possibly the most fun you can have while gaming.

This game is a masterpiece.  Just Cause 2 is like playing a B-grade action movie: It couldn't care less about realism and just goes all-out on the explosions and badassery.  The game throws normal physics, any remotely serious storyline, and common sense of all kinds out the window in favour of pure, uninhibited fun. You are almost never limited by such annoyances present in other games as dying, getting from point A to point B, invisible walls, cutscenes, or morality. You're handed 400 square miles of awesome on a plate, given a toybox of recklessness and let off the leash.  You play as Rico Rodriguez, a secret agent/demigod equipped with a grappling hook, a bottomless bag of parachutes and the ability to turn any gun he picks up into a WMD. As Rico, you can grapple people to cars, grapple cars to people, parachute onto military bases while shooting everyone, steal helicopters in mid-air and then go on a rampage, and cause many, many explosions. Like, wow. I'm pretty sure it rains gasoline in Panau. Just shooting at cars for a few seconds causes a satisfying Hollywood fireball to blossom forth, and most military bases are practically layered with fuel containers and interestingly volatile SAM sites and communications equipment. Even moving around is fun, grappling the ground with your parachute out to propel yourself forward at sportscar-like speeds.  You can steal jets, take down armies single-handed, run rickshaw bike thingies off cliffs, and go on an entertaining variety of explosion-packed missions. This game offers you an incredible degree of freedom that other games just don't have. Not to mention there's a community-made multiplayer mod, where you can embark on epic explosive adventures with your friends, use boost plugins to propel your car to lightspeed, and have derbies with fire engines on top of airborne strip clubs.  I can't reccomend this game enough. It's just beautiful to play. I mean, how can you go wrong with a game about a demigod secret agent with a grappling hook using dictator statue heads as wrecking balls?

Just Cause 2 is a game where you play as a generic Latino mercenary-type hardass named Rico Rodriguez. The game takes place in a generic 3rd-world Asian police state, run by a generic dictatorship. The plot is rife with clichéd characters, painfully bad voice acting, and 'why the hell am I doing this' moments. That being said, no one's playing this game for the plot. The plot in an adult video is just an excuse to get people porking, and the plot in Just Cause 2 is just an excuse for Rico to blow things up.  The island of Panau is completely open, and you can go wherever and do whatever (outside of instanced or timed missions.) There is a strong incentive to explore, as you can find upgrades hidden inside fishing huts, on top of skyscrapers, and just about anywhere you can think of.  Exploring is amazingly fun, as the island of Panau is huge and has dozens of unique environments: scorched deserts, rainforests, tropical shorelines, snowy mountaintops, and a sprawling metropolis. Any vehicle you see is yours for the taking, although there are obvious repercussions for stealing military vehicles.  PROS:  + You get money for blowing things up + Exploring is extremely fun + SO MANY different vehicles: cars, trucks, jeeps, hummers, tour buses, motorcycles, scooters, rickshaws, motor boats, jet boats, tugboats, prop planes, small jet planes, large jet planes, armored trucks, helicopters, fighter jets... not to mention Rico's signature hang glider + Graphics were amazing by 2010 standards, and still pretty decent for 2014 standards + The grappling hook is stupidly fun to screw around with + Absolutely HUGE, beautifully designed map + Enemy military is still challenging, even with lots of weapons  CONS: - Story resembles something written by a middle-schooler - Plane controls are ABYSMAL (wasd) - Can be difficult to find specific weapons/ammo (honestly, just Google where the rocket launcher spawns and you'll be good)  OVERALL: B+ Good if you want to just blow things up with impunity, or if you need a sandbox-shooter to hold you over until GTA V comes out on PC. Definitely worth buying if it's on sale (frequently goes for $4.99 or less.)

Just Cause takes it a little further to give you a moral reason to fight.  There are a few downsides that arent too drastic. Sometimes travelling may seem to take forever and the landscape can get a little repetitive. As you play though, you will realise that its just a matter of finding the right transport. Also, a key aspect of the game is 'Chaos' which is generated when you destroy government marked utilities, complete missions and destroy millitary establishments. There's a slight problem with 'popup' of some details, but it's not too distracting. It's most noticable when flying over the ocean, as you see various bits of coral pop into view in the shallow waters. Other than that, the graphics are beautifully done.

While the game slowly ages, the graphics still remain stunning. The single player 'career/campaign' is repetitive with all missions starting the same and having little variety, but their only real use is to unlock more of the map and more options, and are relatively fun, but not the point of the game. Just Cause 2 is a huge free-roam world with so much to do, and so much more now that there's a multiplayer mod for it. Definitely worth the money, and you'd be making a mistake not to buy this on sale.

This game is a masterpiece.  Just Cause 2 is like playing a B-grade action movie: It couldn't care less about realism and just goes all-out on the explosions and badassery.  The game throws normal physics, any remotely serious storyline, and common sense of all kinds out the window in favour of pure, uninhibited fun. You are almost never limited by such annoyances present in other games as dying, getting from point A to point B, invisible walls, cutscenes, or morality. You're handed 400 square miles of awesome on a plate, given a toybox of recklessness and let off the leash.  You play as Rico Rodriguez, a secret agent/demigod equipped with a grappling hook, a bottomless bag of parachutes and the ability to turn any gun he picks up into a WMD. As Rico, you can grapple people to cars, grapple cars to people, parachute onto military bases while shooting everyone, steal helicopters in mid-air and then go on a rampage, and cause many, many explosions. Like, wow. I'm pretty sure it rains gasoline in Panau. Just shooting at cars for a few seconds causes a satisfying Hollywood fireball to blossom forth, and most military bases are practically layered with fuel containers and interestingly volatile SAM sites and communications equipment. Even moving around is fun, grappling the ground with your parachute out to propel yourself forward at sportscar-like speeds.  You can steal jets, take down armies single-handed, run rickshaw bike thingies off cliffs, and go on an entertaining variety of explosion-packed missions. This game offers you an incredible degree of freedom that other games just don't have. Not to mention there's a community-made multiplayer mod, where you can embark on epic explosive adventures with your friends, use boost plugins to propel your car to lightspeed, and have derbies with fire engines on top of airborne strip clubs.  I can't reccomend this game enough. It's just beautiful to play. A very notice open-world third person shooter with a bunch of story and a lot of explosions. The typical Just Cause formula.  There's simply nothing bad you can say about this game, it's fun, challenging enough to not get boring easily, it becomes a sandbox after the main story ends and there's a crapton of collectables.  Gameplay: The game starts out relatively fast paced, the tutorial is fluently designed to work with the game, but features like using the grapling hook to pull down enemies from high points, i.e. watchtowers, or connecting them to the ingame world, i.e. surroundings or vehicles, are simply sandbox gimmicks: Fun to use every now and then, but essentially you'll forget about them in the heat of combat.  Graphics: I can't say too much about this part, as my computer forces me to play on low-ish settings, even then the graphics are simply stunning, with little details such as Rico's clothes 'looking' wet after coming out of water. Especially explosions look amazing.  AI: Could be better, but it's pretty advanced. Whenever available, any AI combatants will use any stationary turrets in their surroundings. A great example of this is the gangs fighting military forces (the military wins most of the time), after which the military forces generally use the gang-vehicle's stationary turret. Although their aim on moving targets could certainly improve.  Controls: Of course, controls are customizeable but are easily learned nonetheless, the game supports controller input as well. I do really dislike the default map button assignment, which is F1 for some reason, playing on a laptop would force me to hit Fn and F1 all the time, but I simply changed it to M, which makes more sense imo.
